title: 107_s2717
content: The Act titled "White-Collar Crime Penalty Enhancement Act of 2002" establishes criminal penalties for conspiracy to commit offenses or defraud the United States. Section 371 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for conspiracy to commit offenses against the United States or defraud the government. Each person involved in the conspiracy will face fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the specific offense. SEC. 3 amends penalties for mail and wire fraud to 10 years. SEC. 4 increases penalties for violations of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. SEC. 5 amends sentencing guidelines for certain white-collar offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to reflect the seriousness of offenses and penalties outlined in the Act, especially related to fraud offenses. The Commission will also consider modifying guidelines to deter and punish such offenses effectively. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to address whether guideline offense levels and enhancements are sufficient to deter and punish offenses, including adding a specific offense characteristic for fraud committed by corporate officers. The Commission will also ensure consistency with other directives and consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances for exceptions to the guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal Sentencing Guidelines to address necessary changes, assure compliance with sentencing purposes, and consider exceptions based on circumstances. SEC. 6. CORPORATE RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTS. Chapter 63 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, Sec. 1348, which mandates that periodic financial reports filed by issuers with the Securities Exchange Commission must be accompanied by a written certification from the chairman of the board, CEO, and CFO. This certification must affirm the accuracy and fairness of the financial statements and disclosures in the report. The new section, Sec. 1348, mandates that financial reports must be certified by key executives. Criminal penalties are imposed for violations, with fines up to $1,000,000 and imprisonment up to 10 years for willful violations. "Sec. 1348 requires corporate officers to certify financial reports, with penalties including fines up to $1,000,000 and imprisonment for willful violations."
